Her music has evolved, too. Amanda Leigh (the title is her given name), Mandy's recently released sixth album, is chock-full of introspective odes to self-discovery and the roller-coaster ride of relationships. Fortunately, Mandy's own love life is now firmly on track. But her marriage in March to singer-songwriter Ryan Adams has garnered unwelcome attention-earlier in the day, Mandy and her new husband were accompanied on their hike by paparazzi. "It was like 9 in the morning, I'm having my period, I have a huge pimple on my face, and all of a sudden some guy pops out from behind a porta-potty," Mandy says, not bothering to disguise her annoyance. She didn't then, either: "I said, 'Man, this is a private street.' He goes, 'I'm sorry.' I was like, 'No, you're not. If you were, you wouldn't be here.'"

Mandy may not be shy about calling out an overly aggressive snapper, but even after a decade in the spotlight, she remains accessible. She offers up a "bless you" when a stranger across the gallery sneezes and eagerly obliges when a tourist-mistaking her for just another young Angeleno-asks her to snap his photo in front of a fountain ("I'll take another, just in case," she says). And after a fierce wind sends this writer's drink sailing all over Mandy's See by Chloe bag, she barely bothers to brush it off. "Are you kidding me?" she says. "It's just iced tea."

And it's that duality-sweet yet strong-that Mandy's closest friends admire. "She can say 'good gracious' and 'fuck' in the same sentence, and they both sound convincing," says singer-songwriter Rachael Yamagata, who co-wrote a song for Mandy's last record. "She has this beautiful purity and this up-for-anything edge. She really is otherworldly in that way."

Mandy was decidedly down-to-earth during the making of her latest album. Instead of renting a recording studio, she and co-writer/producer Mike Viola moved into sound engineer Ducky Carlisle's modest home outside Boston and laid down tracks in the basement. Mandy often recorded in her flannel PJ's, with a candle burning nearby. "I'd never sung sitting down before," she says, "but there was something so intimate about the way we were doing the record. It was just the three of us, and we made the most of what we had. Typically, in a studio, every day you're conscious of how much money it's costing, but there was no pressure. It was like, let's go for this song today, and if it wasn't working, we'd come back to it later."

Jon Leshay, who's managed Mandy since the beginning of her career, says that Amanda Leigh marks an important turning point in her career. "Mandy's a perfectionist, ridiculously hard on herself," he says. "But with this record, she was able to let go. She just let things be, rather than go over them 800 times. I think she realized there's a particular kind of beauty in that."

Spend an afternoon with Mandy and it becomes clear that she's feeling a newfound, hard-won fulfillment not only professionally but personally. She's understandably protective of her marriage ("the more you give away, the less that's there for you"), but in the end, she can't help gushing. Mandy calls Ryan "my best friend, someone I have so much respect for." The pair were wed in a Savannah chapel after a month-long engagement, with no family or friends in attendance. "We figured, 'Yeah, why not? Let's do it,'" she says. "It was never important for a wedding to be about anything other than me and my partner. A big celebration was never my cup of tea."

The nuptials were pulled together so quickly that there wasn't time to size her wedding ring. She still hasn't gotten around to it. The two delicate eternity bands on her ring finger are part of her engagement set; they're a smidge big, too, which is why she rarely wears them at home. "I'm so klutzy," she says. "I'm constantly worried that they're gonna fall off."

Truth be told, not long ago, Mandy doubted she'd ever slip anything on that particular finger. "I didn't know if marriage was something that was super important to me," she says. "I thought, maybe I don't need that in my life." Part of the disillusionment: Last year, after 30 years of matrimony, Mandy's high-school sweetheart parents divorced. "It shakes you to the core," she says. "I didn't take the decision [to get married] lightly. I ventured into it realistically. But life takes you places you wouldn't have expected. I'm really content with what was in the cards for me."

The newlyweds live in the L.A. home Mandy bought seven years ago, and together they've settled into a low-key routine that includes shopping in their funky East Side neighborhood, playing board games ("I tend to be really competitive when it comes to Scattergories"), and evenings in watching documentaries (a favorite lately: Style Wars, about New York City graffiti artists). Ryan handles most of the cooking; Mandy cleans up afterward. "We're quiet people who live a normal, boring life," she says. Rounding out the family: Joni, a 1 1/2-year-old terrier mix, named after Joni Mitchell, that Mandy adopted from a shelter. "She came right over and put her little chin on my knee, and sort of sighed, like, 'I'm home,'" she recalls. "I just knew."

Similarly, Mandy follows her gut when it comes to nourishing her body and mind. "I'm into having balance in my life and trying to treat myself well," she says. That means hikes, plus Pilates three to four times a week and acupuncture sessions. "I've come to love acupuncture," she says. "It's so restorative. It brings me back to myself." She also goes to therapy, which she first tried a little over a year ago. "You go in thinking, 'Wow, I have nothing to talk about. Where is this hour gonna go?' And before you know it, time's up," she says. "I don't have to burden my friends with the same things over and over again, and it's fascinating to get an unbiased point of view, to not feel like anybody would judge you. It's very freeing."

Title: Mix Up Your Workout
Content:
You don't have to reinvent the exercise wheel every time you want to change your fitness workouts. With any base exercise, there are dozens of ways to tweak it so that you're constantly challenging, working, and toning your muscles.

Here, we take one of our favorite pieces of equipment (the stability ball) and one of our favorite exercises (the lunge) and show you six new ways to mix them into your routine.

Exercise

Reverse Lift



Holding a small stability ball between your feet, drape yourself over another stability ball. Roll down into a pushup as you straighten your body and lift your legs up. (Do not arch your back.) 1Exercise

Windshield Wiper



Works core
Lie on your back with your arms out to the sides. Squeeze the stability ball between your feet. Lift your legs toward the ceiling so they're over your hips. Keeping your right shoulder pressed to the floor, let your legs lower toward the left as far as you can. Use your core to pull the ball back to the starting position and repeat to the other side. 1-2Exercise

Back Rollout



Kneel in front of the ball and place your hands on top of it, shoulder-width apart, arms straight. Roll the ball out in front of you, keeping your core tight. The ball can roll under your forearms at this point. Roll the ball back to start. 4Exercise

Seated Bug



Sit on the ball with your feet flat on the floor, hips square, and your palms fisted and facing each other. Tighten your core to keep the ball still. Lift your right knee until your hip forms a 90-degree angle while simultaneously lifting your left arm overhead. Lower and repeat on the other side without letting the ball move. Perform 20 reps. Too easy? Grab a pair of 2- or 3-pound dumbbells. 1Exercise

Prone Cobra



Lie facedown on a stability ball, keeping it under your belly. With legs straight and using light dumbbells, do a reverse fly: Squeeze your shoulder blades together and pull arms into a wide arc. Hold at your highest point for a second. Lower and repeat.2-3Exercise

Stability Ball Pike



Place your lower legs on a stability ball and get in a pushup position. Use your core to pull the ball toward your face as you raise your butt high to form a pike. Hold for a second, then roll back out until your body is straight. 2-3Exercise

Side Lunge with Upright Row



Hold a pair of 5-pound dumbbells and let your arms hang in front of you, palms facing your body. Next, step the right leg into a side lunge, while simultaneously pulling your hands up your body until your elbows are even with your shoulders. Lower your arms and return to start. Repeat to the left and alternate sides.2-3Exercise

Penta Lunge



Step forward with your right foot into a regular lunge. Next, push back and lunge out 45 degrees to the right (in front of you). Then lunge to the right side, push up, and lunge 45 degrees behind you. Finish by stepping back into a regular reverse lunge. Repeat with the left leg and alternate for two sets of each sequence. 2Exercise

Step Lunge Pulse



Stand in front of a step (or Bosu or foam pad) and step onto it, placing your left foot flat on top. Sink your weight down into a lunge. Keeping your foot on the step, press up and then sink down again for another rep. Perform 10 reps and then switch sides for two sets. 2Exercise

0Lunge Kick and Curl



Grab two dumbbells and step left leg back into a reverse lunge. As you press up, kick your back leg in front while curling the dumbbells toward your shoulders. Step left leg back into a reverse lunge and repeat. Do 10 reps before switching legs; do two to three sets.2-3Exercise

1Overhead Lunge Walk



Hold a light barbell or two dumbbells at arm's length over your head, palms facing forward. Pull your abs in toward your spine to stabilize your core. Step your left leg forward into a lunge, then press up and step forward into a lunge with your right leg. 3-4Exercise

2Flamingo Lunge



Hold a medicine ball in front of your chest at shoulder height. Step back with your right foot into a reverse lunge. As you push up to start, press the ball over your head as you lift your right leg in front, bending your right knee to 90 degrees. Balance for a second. Lower the weight and repeat on the same leg for 10 reps. Then repeat with your left leg and alternate for two to three sets on each side.2-3

Title: Alicia Sacramone's Workout
Content:
Gymnast Alicia Sacramone often puts in seven hours a dayworking towards her dream: an Olympic gold in Beijing.

Here, she shows us the moves that keep her buff enough to do afull-twisting double flip on floor.







Read our interview with Alicia

Check out Alicia's playlist

Find out other Olympians' workouts






Exercise

Hanging Leg Lift



Hang on a bar or a tilted bench (A).Slowly lift your knees toward your chest (B).Lift as high as possible, curling your hipsup. Hold for two seconds at the top,then slowly lower down.

Feeling strong?Trythis move with straight legs (C).

2-3Exercise

Lunge Walk with Bar



Hold a bar at shoulder height, palms facing out and yourfeet hip-width apart. You need room to walk about 20 steps. Step forward withyour right foot, and lower your body so that your right thigh is parallel tothe floor and your left thigh is perpendicular to the floor (your left kneeshould bend and almost touch the floor). Stand and bring your left foot up nextto your right, then repeat with the left leg lunging forward.

2-3Exercise

Pike Up with the Ball



Place your lower legs on a stability ball and get in apushup position (A). Use your core to pull the ball toward your face as youraise your butt high to form a pike (B). Hold for a second, then roll back outuntil your body is straight.

2-3Exercise

Standing Side Jumps



Stand next to a step or block with your feet shoulder-widthapart and your hands in front of you for balance (A). Get into a quarter squatand jump as high as you can laterally onto the block or step, landing on bothfeet (B). As soon as you touch the block, step down the other side and repeatin the opposite direction, so you jump both ways.

2-3

Title: What’s Your Foot Type?
Content:
Our shoe guide is packed with this season's best kicks for every fitness routine and foot type. But before you slide into a new pair of our latest and greatest, it's important to figure out your basic foot type (hint: It's based on your arches), and how to choose your shoes accordingly.

Take this 30-second foot test to determine your foot type, courtesy of our colleagues at Runner's World!

Title: Bath Product Central
Content:
Nothing says "I love me" like a luxurious tubful of warm, fluffy suds before going to sleep But it's not all bubbles and bare skin. To get the most from your water world, you have to apply the principles of thermodynamics, biology, and chemistry. You remember this stuff, right? Didn't think so. Which is why we tapped scientists, researchers, and beauty gurus for a refresher course and some help concocting a formula for the ultimate tub trip (no lab-geek goggles required). Now, be a good sponge and soak it up.

Pre-Tub Prep...

Tweak the temp
You want to soak in water that's 97 to 99 degrees--just like you are. Any hotter and your nervous system goes into overdrive, as it struggles to adjust your internal thermostat. Translation: Might as well drop a blow-dryer into the water. Avoid shocking your system by measuring the temperature of your tub.
WH Pick: Mobi Digital Bath and Room Thermometer ($13, target.com)

Cue up the tunes
A 2006 Temple University study found that people who listen to music during a colonoscopy require less sedation. Now, you don't need to be unconscious to enjoy a bath. But if Lily Allen can make an intestinal probe more pleasant, just imagine what she could do for tub time. So crank your tunes, and think, "At least I didn't have a colonoscopy today."
WH Pick: Every Audio Shower Mirror A transmitter beams music from your iPod to water-resistant speakers hanging on the shower wall. ($100, hammacher.com)

Dim down
Back in Bedrock days, the brain's pineal gland learned to secrete melatonin, an unwinding hormone, at dusk. To simulate twilight in your bathroom, turn off the lights and cleanse by candlelight.
WH Pick: SpaFinder No-Flame Candle A flame-shaped LED mimics the light produced by a lit wick--flicker and all--minus the messy wax and fire risk. Coolest part: The light goes out when you blow on the bulb. Yabba dabba yawn. ($12, 800-367-2866)

In You Go...

Sink deeper
Dunk underwater until just your face peeks out. "The more of you that touches that water, the more you benefit," says Reinhard Bergel, Ph.D., coauthor of The Spa Encyclopedia. Warmth dilates capillaries, increasing the stream of nutrients and oxygen to every cell in the body--relaxing you from your neck to your toes.
WH Pick: Deep Water Bath Overflow Cover Block the overflow drain with this suction cup and fill your tub as high as you want. ($7, amazon.com)

Outsmart Mrs. Bubble
Is sudsy goodness making your vajayjay itchy? One possible explanation: Many bubble-bath formulas contain a foaming agent called sodium lauryl sulfate. When SLS isn't soaping you up, it can be found breaking down engine grease on garage floors. Best to go chem-free.
WH Pick: Naturopathica Aqua Latte Foaming Bath Milk Company founder Barbara Close insists on a gentler bubbler, made from coconut oil. ($48 for 8 oz, naturopathica.com)

Pass the salt
It turns out that Grandpa was right: Epsom salts are practically a cure-all. Their key component is magnesium, a powerhouse mineral that regulates hundreds of enzymes in our bodies. So it's no big surprise that all kinds of pesky health complaints--from cramps to headaches to irritability--have been linked to magnesium deficiency. Twice a week, pour 2 cups of the salty goodness into your bath instead of bubbles.
WH Pick: Rite Aid Epsom Salt ($3 for 64 oz, drugstore.com)

Dump bumps
Red bumps on your bikini line are skinspeak for WTF?! Avoid irritating your follicles by soaking in warm water for 5 minutes before shaving, says Gregory G. Papadeas, D.O., a Denver-based dermatologist. Water loosens hair follicles to help stubble slip out nice and easy. And of course, don't forget a skin-pleasing shaving cream.
WH Pick: SkinMilk Shaving Milk It's fortified with vitamins A, D, and E to soothe as you smooth. ($5 for 8 oz, drugstore.com)

Feed your mane
Warm water opens the outer layer of each strand of hair, so whatever you put in your hair when it's wet penetrates deeper, says Lorraine Massey, founder of New York City's Devachan Salon. Opt for coconut butter, which is rich in lock-thickening fatty acids. Let it sit for at least 20 minutes, then rinse with warm water.
WH Pick: Artisana Raw Organic Coconut Butter ($9 for 8 oz, superorganicfoods.com)

Play dirty
Steam dilates pores, making your tub a good place for deep cleansing. Bust grease with a clay mask. The oleophilic sediments in clay absorb dirt and oil as it dries on your skin, making your pores appear smaller and your skin look tighter.
WH Pick: Epoch Glacial Marine Mud This pristine mud is collected from a remote estuary on the coast of British Columbia, 2 hours by boat from the nearest road. ($25 for 7 oz, nuskin.com)

Time's Up...

Plan to zonk
Everyone's body temperature falls in the evening, but some people's drops faster than others'. A Cornell University study showed that those lucky people fall asleep faster and sleep more deeply. Study author Patricia Murphy, Ph.D., suggests emerging from a warm bath 60 to 90 minutes before bedtime to stimulate a quick dive in degrees.

Seal the deal
Moisturize with the same stuff Cleopatra used: pure oil. Because it doesn't mix with water, oil forms a film over wet skin, sealing in moisture, says Neil Sadick, M.D., a New York City dermatologist. If you have time to air-dry, skip the towel, lube up, wrap yourself in a robe, and let your skin soak it all in.
WH Picks: Origins Nourishing Oil for Body and Massage ($29 for 3.4 oz, origins.com for stores); Warmrails Wonderbar Hang this heated bar from your towel rack to keep your robe toasty. ($45, bedbathstore.com)

Clean sweet
The organic material in soap scum makes your tub a buffet for mold spores. Starve them by cleaning once a week. But ditch the chlorine bleach. We wouldn't rub that solution on our skin--it dissolves human body tissue -- yet we scrub our tubs with it and then soak in the excess. Mama Nature would not be happy.
WH Pick: Method Tub + Tile This biodegradable spray is like Mr. Clean's vegan brother -- equally buff, only healthier. This, Mama likes. ($5, methodhome.com)

Title: Relieve Muscle Pain
Content:
Your perfect, grapefruit-shaped glutes aren't the only things suggesting you've been working hard. Your tired, creaky muscles are aching for a little attention too. Fortunately you can melt away muscle tension with a few good rubs and keep your pain from sidelining your workouts. Muscle creams are generally easy to find, and they soothe varying levels of soreness - even after just one application. Most work by boosting circulation enough to remove lactic acid, a buildup of muscular debris that occurs when you pump blood to your muscles faster than it flows back to your heart, says Allan Levy, Ph.D., coauthor of the Sports Injury Handbook. To help you loosen up, WH editors really pushed it (we ran harder and longer, put in extra time at the gym, and signed up for a new Pilates class), then tested six salves to see whether they hit the spot.

Aloette Soothing Muscle Rejuvenator

2-oz tube sold as part of Aloette's Stress Free Living Kit: $45

Tester Says:"This lightweight lotion left a cool layer of relief on my shoulders and back, and it lasted for a few hours after my weight-lifting session."

Key Ingredients:Menthol, witch hazel, and St. John's wort oil

Why it Works
Menthol combines with energizing witch hazel, a tingling astringent that draws inflammation from the area, says Sue Williams, N.D., a naturopathic physician at Phoenix Body Positive in Arizona. It also contains St. John's wort, "an herb which has tannin and amentoflavone, components that also reduce inflammation," she says.

Best for moderate soreness (like an achy deskbound back) and anytime you want continuous cooling relief. It smells a lot better than most rubs too - like cloves, not medicine. You can apply this cream frequently without irritating your skin - or your neighbors.

Hyland's Arnica Montana 1X

$6.50 for 1 oz, Homeopathic Laboratories

Tester Says:"Surgery left my back muscles constantly sore, but this thick, nontingling ointment eased most of the tension and pain about 10 minutes after I applied. It also absorbed quickly, leaving my skin super smooth."

Key Ingredients:Arnica and beeswax

Why it Works
It's virtually pure arnica (a European herb that grows from Spain all the way to southern Scandinavia), which increases blood flow, moving old blood (like bruises) away from an injury and bringing in fresh healing reserves. Beeswax thickens the cream to help bind the arnica to your skin so it won't rub off.

Best for super-sore muscles and actual sprains. You can apply it as frequently as needed, and it's virtually fragrance-free (there's a hint of black licorice scent, but it's not offensive). You can also dab a little on bruises - just avoid broken skin.

Badger Sore Muscle Rub

$8 for 2 oz, Uncommon Scents

Tester Says: "This waxy balm completely calmed my shoulders and upper back after a day spent hunched over my computer, but it also left my hands sticky - so I waited just a few minutes before -putting on a shirt."

Key Ingredients:Cayenne extract, ginger, and extra virgin olive oil

Why it Works
Extra virgin olive oil is moisturizing and ultra-penetrating, so the cayenne pepper extracts (better known as capsaicin) can get into skin to work on reducing pain. Capsaicin (which dates back to the mid-16th century, when cayenne pepper was used for everything from stroke prevention to toothache treatment) works as a counter-irritant, producing a small amount of swelling and redness, which warms the area and increases healing circulation. The slight skin irritation it can cause helps mask deep-seated pain.

Best for preemptive protection. The rub quickly increases circulation, so it can help warm and loosen your muscles faster before your workout. The spicy ginger smell also delivers a mental wake-up. It's good for minor soreness, but if you need to apply it more than twice, switch to a more potent balm.

Kathleen Lewis Stiff And Sore

$24 for 4 oz, Vickerey

Tester Says:"After my first Pilates session in 2 months, I applied this light cream to my abs. It was a little greasy, but the next day I could stretch my arms over my head without feeling like I was going to tear myself in half."

Key Ingredients:Arnica, comfrey, and peppermint

Why it Works
Tea tree oil helps arnica quickly penetrate (the oil has -chemical properties that cause it to dissolve into your skin), and the comfrey is a centuries-old (we're talking monks in the Middle Ages), homeopathic bruise remedy that stimulates tissue repair and nerve regeneration.

Best for deep-tissue massage. The balm contains grapeseed oil, which makes it slick. It will also soothe your sinuses, and the strong peppermint odor is -pleasant - like Doublemint gum.

Tiger Balm Pain Relieving Ointment

$5 for .63 oz, Drugstore.com

Tester Says:"My calves ball into rocks after I run. Within seconds of applying the slightly slippery ointment, my calves started tingling until they were practically numb. I woke up the next morning and the knots had unraveled."

Key Ingredients: Menthol and camphor

Why it Works
These two ingredients make up a super-potent 11 percent of the balm - a highly concentrated dose compared with the amount in other balms, Dr. Levy says. Menthol (derived from peppermint and other mint oils that contain anesthetic properties) soothes and helps counter the topical numbing effect of the camphor. Camphor comes from an Asian evergreen tree, and, though it produces a cooling feeling like menthol, it tends to be stronger. "Camphor causes heat that rushes blood to the area and numbs it," Dr. Williams explains.

Best for intense postworkout soreness. Its strength can help dissolve pain, and the increased circulation it causes stimulates healing. But use this balm before you get into bed - and even then, wash your sheets - because the strong trainer's-room odor can linger for a few days.

Zip's Muscle Rub

$11 for 2.5 oz, Zip's Natural Sport

Tester Says: "I managed to run 7 miles (2 more than usual) without keeling over. Climbing a flight of stairs afterward? That was tough. I felt nothing when I first rubbed in the waxy formula (and I had to warm it in my hands first to thin it and make it easier to apply), but the next morning, my thighs were functional."

Key Ingredients: Arnica, menthol, wild yam, white willow extracts

Why it Works
Menthol helps ease pain, and wild yam (a root used by the Mayans and Aztecs to help relax muscles during childbirth) and white -willow bark reduce inflammation. "They derive aspirin from white willow bark, so it's a topical pain reliever. It contains salicin, which is both anti-inflammatory and analgesic," Dr. Williams says. "And wild yam has alkaloid properties, which means that it can help ease muscle contractions."

Best for sore muscles that spasm. Apply it just before bed to keep overworked legs from twitching in your sleep. It looks like an Altoids tin and smells just like the mints inside.

Title: How to Get Back Pain Relief
Content:
At 26, I felt feisty, athletic, and downright invincible. It wasn't until I broke a mean sweat at the gym on a random afternoon and something gave out in my lower body that my perspective began to change. My lumbar, bum, and left leg screamed like a trio of Mega Millions lottery winners -- the sensation was so intense that I was bed-bound the next day. My doctor's advice? Pop prescription-strength Aleve and get some rest (as if I had a choice). Sure enough, my pain eased after a week, and a month later, I seemed like myself again.

Though I felt entirely alone in my achy breaky back pain, it turns out I'm just another stat. Studies show it's the number one cause of limitations to physical activity for people under the age of 45, and it's the number two reason we call in sick (just after colds and flu and that sadistic Oprah rerun with James Frey). So what gives -- besides our bodies?

"In your 20s, it's most likely caused by a muscle strain or a [problem with a] disk," one of the spongy cushions between the vertebrae, explains Daveed Frazier, M.D., an orthopedic spine surgeon at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York City. (Dr. Frazier also became my specialist.) For most patients, back pain improves within a couple of weeks or so. But while most strains will eventually heal by themselves, an injured disk can grow worse -- that is, unless you take serious steps to prevent future problems. That's why I suggest starting now.

Part of the trouble is that the human spine isn't as strong as one might imagine, and disks are among the weaker links. As early as your 20s, your spine suddenly becomes less willing to tolerate the abuse you put it through; sitting for long periods, slouching, lifting, and even exercising can cause damage. Disks are intended to absorb shock, but over time, they flatten and dry out. And should they bulge (called herniated or ruptured disks), they may end up poking nearby nerves, causing serious pain. Eventually, I was diagnosed with sciatica, which occurs when a herniated disk presses on the roots of the sciatic nerve that runs down each leg. This affects 1 to 2 percent of all people, usually between the ages of 30 and 50. Reminder: I was only 26 at the time. Lucky me.

Six years later...

My back pain (and sciatica) returned -- this time during spinning class while I was training for a honeymoon cycling trip in France. And once again, my doctor prescribed a simple treatment: Rest for 2 to 3 days, ice for 20 minutes every hour for 2 days (if ice doesn't help, try heat compresses), and take over-the-counter pain meds as needed. What made his Rx different this time was that he suggested physical therapy (PT) after the rest period -- and told me to keep moving.

Jeffrey Goldstein, M.D., a spine surgeon at the New York University Hospital for Joint Diseases, couldn't agree more about the need for physical activity -- and physical therapy. "The biggest mistake people make with back pain is to lie around and eat Advil until the pain goes away," he says. For me, a typical 1-hour PT session included assisted stretching, as well as strengthening and stretching my lower torso, hips, and hamstrings. Weekly massages and electric stimulation can also ease muscle tension and help keep pain at bay. Regardless of your regimen, expect to visit a physical therapist 3 days a week for about a month. If you're not better after that, go back to your primary M.D. or see a pain, nerve, or orthopedic specialist. An epidural, more PT, or stronger meds may be in your future.

Haven't got time for the pain

Just because you feel better doesn't mean you're off the hook. Talk to your doctor about trying these six steps to avoid a nasty redux.

1)Build fab abs. "Don't just go for the six-pack," Dr. Frazier says. "Strengthen the muscles that go around your entire spine: the obliques [the diagonal abdominal muscles on the sides of your torso], the abs in front, and the back muscles." This helps evenly distribute impact on your vertebrae. Work your abs three or more times a week for at least 10 minutes at a time; click here forgreat core-builders.

2)Make like Gumby. When your hamstrings, hips, and back are tight, they put extra stress on your spine, which can cause pain later on. Stretch those muscles at least 5 minutes a day before bed and at the end of each workout.

3)Learn the pickup line. You already know to lift everything from a 5-pound bag of groceries to a 50-pound barbell by bending your knees, hugging the object close, and pressing up with your legs and abs. But many make the mistake of twisting to one side as they lift. Not you! Lift facing the same direction as your hips, with equal weight on each leg.

4)Stand (and sit) smart. Mom was right again! Slouching is bad -- it strains your lower back. So does sitting with your knees at the same height as your hips, experts say. Shut everyone up by lowering your knees below hip level while seated "to maintain the natural curve in your back," says Natalia Glenn, a physical therapist in Katonah, New York.

5)Get a brand-new bag. We don't care if your oversize Marc Jacobs makes your office rival more envious than a bald man at a Hugh Grant movie. The heavy-handbag trend is a common cause of back pain in women, according to the American Chiropractic Association. Don't let your purse weigh more than 10 percent of what you do.

6)Stop with the Snickers. Extra jelly in your belly pulls you forward, creating an exaggerated curve in your back. "It puts additional pressure on the disks, which can make them bulge," explains Michele S. Olson, Ph.D., a professor of exercise science at Auburn University Montgomery.

Unfortunately for me, I learned these preventive measures too late to benefit. Instead, I spent a year experimenting with everything from massages and meds to an epidural injection. But my bulging disk would not relent. At one point, the pain was so awful I could barely walk, not to mention leave the house for dinner -- or stay in for sex. That's when Dr. Frazier began t talk surgery. He performed a discectomy, which removed the part of the disk that bulged -- and sure enough, it worked. Eight years later, I have no plans to run a marathon, but I practice yoga and strength train, and I can ride my bike up and down hills with a 37-pound toddler in tow. Next year, who knows? Maybe Provence again.

Title: Low-Fat Healthy Recipe For Chicken Marsala
Content:
Healthy Cooking: Chicken Marsala

Prep: 10 minCook: 15 min

3 Tbsp whole-wheat flour
3 Tbsp white flour
1/4tsp white pepper
1 - 1 1/2 lb chicken cutlets
3c sliced mushrooms
2Tbsp thinly sliced shallots
1/2c Marsala wine
1/2c low-sodium chicken broth
2Tbsp chopped parsley
1/2 tsp chopped fresh thyme leaf

1. In a shallow bowl, combine flours and pepper. Dredge chicken in mixture and set aside.

2. Lightly coat a large, nonstick skillet with cooking spray and heat on medium-high. Add chicken and sauté until lightly browned, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove cutlets to a plate and keep warm.

3. Add mushrooms and shallots to pan; stir for 1 to 2 minutes.

4. Add wine to pan. Reduce to a glaze, scraping any loose brown bits from bottom of pan.

5. Reduce heat and add broth, parsley, and thyme. Stir; cook until broth reduces by half.

6. Return chicken to pan and simmer for 5 minutes. Serve hot.

Makes 4 servings. Per serving: 224 cal, 2 g fat (1 g sat), 400 g sodium, 20 g carbs, 1 g fiber, 27 g protein

Make it a meal
Mash 1/2 cup boiled red bliss potatoes (leave the skins on for maximum nutrition) with 1 Tbsp fat-free cream cheese, 1 Tbsp skim milk, and salt and pepper to taste. Serve alongside 1/2 cup peeled, sliced carrots that have been boiled, drained, and glazed with 1 tsp honey. This pair of belly-filling sides adds a mere 116 calories, for a dinnertime total of 340.

For more healthy Italian recipes, check out our Recipe Finder.

Title: Chef Challenge: Snapper Fish Recipe
Content:
Healthy food recipes that are under 500 calories, 20 grams of fat, and 650 milligrams of sodium? Wow!

3/4 c uncooked long-grain brown rice
4 Tbsp orange juice
2Tbsp lime juice
2 Tbsp olive oil
4 Tbsp finely chopped cilantro
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 pinch (about 1/16 tsp) sugar
4 snapper fillets (5 oz each), rinsed and patted dry
1 3/4 c medium salsa
1can (15 oz) no-salt-added black beans, drained and rinsed
2 c chopped pineapple

1. Preheat oven to 400°F and cook rice according to package instructions.

2. In a large, shallow bowl, combine orange and limejuices, olive oil, two tablespoons cilantro, garlic, and sugar, plus salt and pepper to taste. Add snapper fillets and marinate for 15 to 20 minutes.

3. In a 3-quart baking dish, combine rice, salsa, beans, pineapple, and 1 tablespoon cilantro. Place snapper over mixture, overlapping fillets if necessary. Spoon remaining marinade over fish.

4. Bake fish uncovered until it is cooked through and opaque, about 25 to 30 minutes. Sprinkle remaining cilantro on top and serve.

Makes 4 servings. Per serving: 466 calories, 10 g fat (2 g saturated), 594 mg sodium, 54 g carbs, 5 g fiber, 37 g protein

If you want another fish recipe, try this low fat-recipe for sea bass.

Title: Workout At Home: Cardio Routine
Content:
You don't need a treadmill to get in a great cardio workout--you can burn flab and shape up fast with the simple mountain climber routine. Do as many as you can with good form, rest for a few seconds, and go again. Continue in this manner until you reach 50.

Make this a part of your workout at home or gym routine. Do one set of 50 reps (with each leg), rest 60 seconds, and repeat one to two times. (For a total of 2 to 3 sets).

How to do it: Assume a pushup position with your arms straight and your body in a straight line from your head to your ankles. Now raise your left knee toward your chest and place the balls of your feet on the floor--as if you were in sprinter's stance. Brace your abs and then quickly switch leg positions, so that you simultaneously kick your left leg back and bring your right leg forward. Alternate back and forth as fast as you can.

More workouts from Michelle Obama's trainer:
The 9-Minute Arm Workout

The Ultimate Hip and Thigh Blaster
BONUS: The Simplest Diet Ever

Title: Tofu Kimchi Stew Recipe
Content:
PREP TIME: 20 minutes

COOK TIME: 25 minutes



1.5 oz dried shiitake mushrooms

1/2 oz dried kelp

2 tsp vegetable oil

10 oz kimchi, chopped

2 garlic cloves, minced

350 grams firm tofu, cubed

3 green onion, white and green parts, sliced

1 small eggplant, cubed


1 Tbsp soybean paste (doenjang)


1. In separate bowls, soak mushrooms and kelp for 20 minutes. Squeeze excess water out of mushrooms and slice.



2. Heat oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add kimchi and garlic; cook for 2 minutes. Add mushrooms, tofu, scallions and eggplant; cook for 4 minutes then remove from heat.



3. In a large saucepan, bring 6 cups of water to boil. Mix in soybean paste and simmer for 3 minutes. Add tofu mixture to saucepan and simmer for 10 minutes. Chop rehydrated kelp, add it to the stew and simmer for 5 minutes more.



Makes four servings. Per Serving: 154 cal, 5 g fat (1 g sat), 22g carbs, 227 mg sodium, 6 g fiber, 10g protein

Title: Ego Boosters
Content:
Whether it's grief from the boss, or the numbers on the scale, our confidence is constantly at risk. According to Carol Rossi, a yoga instructor based in Los Angeles, confidence can be developed the second you challenge yourself. "The practice of yoga poses is a mirror for the practice of life," she says. "So over time you will find yourself more confident in situations off the mat." They key is realizing that while your body may never bend like Seane Corn's in a standing forward bend (uttanasana), you can still get the same benefits. "Confidence is developed by realizing that, in yoga, you're not just trying to achieve some ideal shape, but are working to appreciate your gifts and limitations," Rossi says. In other words, the goal in uttanasana is not to wipe the sweat from your brow on your shins. So try spending less time looking in the mirror and a little more looking within yourself at how the pose feels. Try approaching these three familiar, accessible poses with that mindset, then stop and notice how you feel when you finish.


Tree pose (vrksasana)

Challenge yourself with a balance pose. You can feel good for trying even if you don't nail it.


Begin in mountain pose (tadasana), palms together at your chest, elbows in. Keep your right foot flat on the mat, bring your left foot to your inner right thigh so your left knee points left. Keep your hips even, correcting your left hip if it hikes up higher than the right. If you're balanced here, try these additional challenges: (a) move your foot higher up on the inside of the thigh and focus on the alignment of your hips; (b) slowly raise your arms over your head, keeping your palms together; (c) close your eyes for the ultimate balance test. Hold your variation of the pose for four to six breaths. Then return to mountain pose and repeat on the other side.


Plank pose

Because this pose requires physical strength and stamina, you'll feel more confident as it gets easier and you can hold it longer.

Begin in downward-facing dog pose (adho mukha svanasana). Shift your body weight forward, keeping your arms and legs straight. Imagine that you're pulling your belly button into your spine and use your core muscles to keep your body aligned in one straight line from your heels to the crown of your head. Don't sink in the shoulders or sag in the back. Hold for four to six breaths. Release by slowly lowering your body to the floor in a straight line, keeping your elbows pulled in by your sides. If this is too challenging, drop your knees to the floor and lower from there.

Warrior I pose (virabhadrasana I)

This pose forces you to take up space-something we hesitate to do when we're down in the dumps or feeling as if we'd like to disappear. Fight those inclinations and embrace your warrior nature.


Begin in mountain pose (tadasana). Step your left foot forward so your feet are a 3 to 4 feet apart. Bend your left knee and turn your right toes out to the right. Align your left heel with the heel of your right foot and your left knee should over your left ankle. Slowly raise both arms overhead, palms facing each other. Keep your hips squared forward. Hold for four to six breaths. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Fitness Tips and Interview: Q&A with Swimmer Kim Vandenberg
Content:
Kim Vanderberg is one of the top female athletes and one of the fastest butterfly swimmers in the world.She's not quite the fastest (she's ranked second), but she's aiming to change that this summer in Beijing.Until then? A meticulous training program, and lots and lots of laps.


What are your goals for the Olympics?

Definitely to medal. At Worlds I got to race the world record
holder, Jessicah Schipper. She won gold and I got silver. I'd love to
beat her. Just the opportunity to race her again would be great. She'll
bring out the best in me again I hope.

How do you handle the stress of it all?

I just try to think of the process and not so much the end result. If
I'm working hard and doing everything I can, in the end it will all
come together. I'm taking care of the small details: sleeping, drinking
water, and eating healthy foods. Having that knowledge that I'm
preparing well gives me comfort and confidence.

What's your schedule like right now?

My typical day is to wake up at 5:15 in the morning, and grab some
coffee and toast. I head to the pool from 6 to 8 A.M., then go to the
weight room from 8:15 to 9:15. I lift and do lots of stretching then.
In the springtime we swim again from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M., then sometimes
I'll do cardio, on an elliptical, for 30 to 40 minutes. Once or twice a
week I do Pilates at night.

I try to go to bed around 9, but I have a hard time sleeping that early. Usually it's closer to 10.

Wow. You must get sore a lot. What are your fitness tips to relieve sore muscles?

I take hot showers--that usually helps. I have a great body oil that I
use from Dr. Hauschka's skin care line. It warms my muscles up. I'll
use that or go get a massage from a trainer. Stretching on a daily
basis really helps me too, and drinking lots of water.

How do you keep yourself going on tough days in the pool?

That is a tough one. I just try to get through it when I'm not
feeling great. I just stay positive, and focus on little details like
my breathing and my body positions. That's really hard though and I'm
still working on that.

I tell myself that the pain I go through is only going to help me in
the end, and I keep that in the back of my mind. If it wasn't for pain
I wouldn't be improving. I try to embrace it and know it will help me.
And all the pain makes the end result that much more satisfying.

What kind of food do you eat when you're training?

I never eat just two or three big meals.Instead I eat four to five smaller meals each day.I try to incorporate a lot of fruits and vegetables and plenty of water. For swimming I need lots of carbs and proteins, but I try to keep it all balanced.

Before practice I usually eat an energy bar--I love the Harvest Grain Bars. After practice I'll eat a sandwich with whole grain bread, turkey or tuna, cheese, lettuce, tomato, cucumber, and lots of veggies in general.I love granola and cottage cheese, and fresh fruits.I can't stop eating pineapples and mangos.I go to Whole Foods every day almost.

We burn so many calories, that it's really important to keep enough food in your body.But I do try to make the foods I eat healthy ones, by eating really good balanced meals without huge portion sizes.

Do you have any guilty pleasures?
Definitely.I really like Italian food.Pretty much all Italian food is my guilty pleasure.Though some Italian is healthy, I like the dishes with the thicker cream sauces.There's this one dish--pumpkin tortellini with cream sauce--that I get at this restaurant we go to.I can't stop eating it!

I also like bacon.I try to eat turkey bacon, but sometimes I'll give in and go with regular.

Do you smell like chlorine all the time?I swim once a week and all my co-workers know exactly which day it is.

Yeah, I really do. I always have to shower right after the pool.A lot of swimmers don't, but I take at least two or three showers a day.Still, I always have that faint scent.When the swimmers come to the weight room after practice, the whole place smells like chlorine.

What kind of swimming tips would you give to a rec swimmer like me?

Try to focus more on your core, not on your legs or your arms.Power comes from the core; from your abs.A lot of rec swimmers kick really hard or flail their arms. They are wasting their energy.Rotation comes from the body.

A good drill is to lie on the water with your arms at your sides, then slowly start to kick to feel the balance between your head and your body.Finally, start to use your arms.You'll realize that your core is where it all comes from.

What's your favorite part of being a swimmer?

The lifestyle.Living a healthy life, working out and being outdoors. We swim outside, unlike people in the Midwest and East Coast. This whole environment is awesome.Having teammates helping me to be the best I can be is a great feeling.

Your least favorite part?

Probably waking up at 5 in the morning.And, in the winter when it's raining.When it's cold outside, I hate being half-naked and freezing the whole time.

Will you continue after the Olympics?

Yeah, I would like to do some fall meets this year, starting in
October. There's a lot of meets in really cool places like Brazil and
South Africa. So hopefully that will work out. I could see myself
competing into 2009 but after that I'm not sure. It depends how I do
this year. So far I just want to get the best times I can. I'm still
getting better, so I don't see any reason to stop.

If you could choose an Olympic sport other than swimming, what would it be?

Probably beach volleyball. I have a lot of fun playing volleyball, and
a lot of friends who played volleyball. I love to watch it. I'm just
not as graceful on land as I am in the water.

Do you ever get a chance to relax?What do you do?

I love going to the beach. I'm 15 minutes from the water.Catching up with friends, watching movies, going out to eat, doing game nights.I'm pretty mellow because I train so much.

I like to read.I'm really into Jodi Picoult right now.I just read about five of her books and liked them all a lot.

What's the one piece of clothing you live in?

My Havaianas sandals, because I'm so used to walking around barefoot.My feet get really hot when I wear real shoes!It's ridiculous.

We have an ongoing discussion with readers about the weirdest thing in their purse. What's your weirdest?
I have a lot of lip gloss.I'm counting four right now.Is that weird?I'm a little obsessed with lip gloss and Chapstick.

If you could go anywhere in the world, where would it be?

I really want to go to South Africa.My stepsister Sarah lives there, and I want to go out on a boat and do those shark cage things.I really want to see great whites.

Just to be clear, I don't want to go in the cage.Other people can go in the cage.But I'll take pictures.
